subject: Sleep
title: Warm Milk Makes You Sleepy
description: A short lesson to help you apply Warm Milk Makes You Sleepy.

hook.text: Grandma said warm milk before bed helps you sleep. The science behind this classic advice is surprisingly weak.

buildup.text: Milk contains tryptophan, an amino acid that the body converts to serotonin and then melatonin.

discovery.text: A glass of milk contains far too little tryptophan to measurably affect brain serotonin or melatonin levels.

twist.text: Warm milk probably works through comfort and ritual. The psychological association with bedtime creates a placebo effect.

climax.text: The placebo effect on sleep is powerful. If warm milk is part of your routine and it works, keep doing it.

punchline.text: Warm milk works because your brain believes it does, not because of tryptophan.

quiz.question: Why does warm milk seem to help with sleep?
options: It contains high doses of melatonin
The comfort and ritual create a placebo effect, not the tryptophan content
It contains a powerful natural sedative
